awd_abstract_narration:
Interval-censored failure time data arise when the time to a failure event is not exactly observed but known or observed only to fall within some time interval. Such data are collected in many fields, including epidemiology, medicine, demographics, economics, finance, psychology and social sciences. This research will propose new cost-effective sampling designs with interval-censored failure time data, in response to the needs of cost reduction and improved power for detecting the exposure-failure-time relationship in epidemiological and biomedical studies. The proposed designs coupled with robust and efficient statistical methods will enable study investigators to collect more informative samples and produce more precise statistical inference at a fixed budget, and they will be especially useful when the failure rate is low and the exposure variable is expensive or difficult to obtain. The graduate student support will be used for theoretical investigation of the proposed methods as well as conducting numerical studies and manuscript preparation.

The new designs proposed in this research are generally two-phase biased-sampling schemes where one observes the expensive exposure at phase II with a probability depending on the phase I information collected on failure times, cheap covariates, or auxiliary variables. All proposed designs will produce biased-sampled interval-censored data with missing covariates. No methods available in the literature can appropriately handle such data. This research will develop robust and efficient semiparametric likelihood-based methods that properly account for the proposed sampling schemes. Nonparametric techniques such as sieve and kernel estimation will be employed. New arguments based on modern empirical process theory will be developed for theoretical investigation of the proposed methods. Efficient computational algorithms and user-friendly software that implement the proposed designs and methods will be created and disseminated. Successful completion of the proposed research will have a significant impact on how future cost-effective epidemiological and biomedical studies be conducted and how data from these studies be efficiently analyzed. This research will also have potential impact on how to perform cost-effective studies and data analyses in other fields that produce interval-censored failure time data, such as demographics, economics, finance, psychology and social sciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.inst_name: University of North Carolina at Charlotte
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH CAROLINA AT CHARLOTTE

por.por_cntn:
This project aims to develop new cost-effective sampling designs and efficient statistical methods to reduce cost and improve efficiency of conducting epidemiological and biomedical studies. The proposed research is well integrated with the educational goal by providing training and research opportunities to undergraduate and graduate students including under-represented minorities.

Intellectual Merit

This project has developed new cost-effective sampling designs with complex failure time data, in response to the needs of cost reduction and improved power in conducting epidemiological and biomedical studies. The proposed sampling designs enable study investigators to collect more informative samples at a fixed budget, and are especially useful when the failure rate is low and the exposure variable is expensive or difficult to obtain. Robust and efficient statistical methods have been developed to reap the benefits gained by the proposed designs. These methods can handle the issues of interval censoring, informative censoring, double censoring, biased sampling, and missing or error-prone covariates. The statistical properties of the proposed methods have been rigorously established. Efficient computational algorithms and software that implement the proposed designs and methods have been developed and disseminated.

Specifically, motivated by the problems in real-world epidemiological and biomedical studies, this research has developed new statistical methods for the analysis of case-cohort studies with informatively interval-censored failure time data or with multiple interval-censored failure time outcomes, the design and analysis of two-phase studies with partly interval-censored data and covariate measurement errors, the analysis of doubly-censored data, and improving the design and estimation efficiency using auxiliary, incomplete or imprecise data. The proposed methods are generally semiparametric likelihood-based and they are robust and efficient. New theoretical arguments based on empirical processes theory, semiparametric inference, and nonparametric techniques have been developed for the large-sample studies of the proposed methods. The results of this research have advanced both statistical theory and methodology.

Broader Impacts

For Epidemiological Studies: Modern epidemiological and biomedical studies demand new cost-effective designs and statistical methods that can handle interval-censored data as well as some other practical issues such as dependent censoring and measurement errors. Due to the lack of effective methods, the current practice of study design and data analysis is mainly to use the imputation-based approaches, that is, to treat the midpoint of the observed interval as the true failure time and then employ the existing designs and methods developed for traditional right-censored data. Apparently, such practice could lead to biased results and erroneous scientific conclusions if the approximated failure time is not close to the true one. The proposed research can provide investigators effective and handy tools to design and analyze their studies, that suffer from interval censoring and some other practical issues, with unbiased results and enhanced power. More importantly, the computer codes have been published and disseminated through publication together with user guides and illustrative examples. The results of this research are expected to have a significant impact on how future cost-effective epidemiological and biomedical studies be conducted and how data from these studies be efficiently analyzed. 

For other academic fields: Interval-censored failure time or time-to-event data arise in many other academic fields beyond biomedicine and epidemiology, such as demographics, economics, finance, political science, psychology and social sciences. For instance, the duration analysis in economics often involves interval-censored time-to-event data. Examples of duration variables include the duration of unemployment or holding a job in labor economics and the duration until purchase of or of holding a major product (e.g., boat and house) in consumer economics. These variables often cannot be exactly observed in practice as the information on them is usually collected only at one or a few time points. The results of this research will have potential impact on how to carry out cost-effective studies and perform proper data analyses in these fields.

For Education: This project has supported the training and research of two PhD students, a Master student, and two undergraduate students. The PI provided training and advice to the students via group seminars and individual meetings. It helped them to improve research and communication skills that are key to their professional developments. The two PhD students will be on the job market in the coming year to pursue their careers in academia or industry of STEM. The Master student got a job in the pharmaceutical industry. One undergraduate student is pursuing her PhD in Applied Mathematics and the other obtained a Master degree in Data Science.

For Research Dissemination: This project resulted in six published peer-reviewed journal papers and one submitted manuscript. It also led to two PhD dissertations, a Master project, and two undergraduate projects including an honors thesis. The computer codes that implement the proposed methods are published and disseminated. The PI and her students gave 14 conference talks, one poster presentation, and four colloquium talks to disseminate the results of this project.


Last Modified: 08/31/2023
Modified by: Qingning Zhou
